text: In 1911, New Jersey limited registration to four days per year, and the process required a prospective voter to list his occupation and the names of his spouse, parents, and landlord, as well as “a satisfactory description of the dwelling in which he lived.” Turnout plummeted.
author: pemalevy

text: Example: Chicago's elite wanted voter registration to be difficult. So they hired investigators to monitor polling locations and offered a $300 reward to anyone who helped “in the apprehension and conviction of anyone who voted illegally in Chicago in 1883.” None were convicted
author: pemalevy

text: Update: A federal judge just denied a request to extend the deadline for absentee ballots in Mississippi's Senate runoff today, though he acknowledged the state's deadline for returning an absentee ballot “is tight—if not impossible—for some voters.”

text: Not just the ballots, but also the mailed in applications for the absentee ballots.
author: pemalevy

text: Mississippi's runoff election is tomorrow. But the deadline to return  absentee ballots was 16 minutes ago (Monday at 5pm). A new lawsuit is challenging the state's onerous vote-by-mail system
author: pemalevy

text: Thanks for having me. It was a great show.
author: pemalevy

text: Covering the end of the dramatic Florida Senate race from DC today. But it was an honor to do it in person over the last week with amazing local reporters @harrisalexc @martindvassolo @Blaskey_S @caitielee0917. #ff to these kickass people.
author: pemalevy

text: Florida's dramatic Senate race came to an end today. Nelson has conceded. Scott won by .12 percent. The race and recount highlighted all the hard work Florida Democrats have to do ahead of 2020 in this critical swing state.
author: pemalevy

text: Trump now claims he didn't know about Matthew Whitaker's anti-Mueller statements as a TV pundit. But reporting tells a different story: That it was Whitaker's anti-Mueller punditry that initially endeared him to Trump.
author: pemalevy

text: Back in DC after a week covering the Florida recount. I will miss the warm weather, but not the insane motorists on I-95. Seriously, what’s up with that?
author: pemalevy

text: There is also an acknowledgement among some Dems in Florida that the Democratic Party here failed to educate their voters about the rules and ensure they got their ballots/registration on time. Dems have a lot of work to do going forward in Florida.
author: pemalevy

text: The judge decided not to change the election rules midstream. But the 2018 midterms did show that there is a problem with Florida's vote-by-mail deadline in a state where mail delivery is not always speedy.
author: pemalevy

text: Bad news for Nelson and Dems in Florida recount: Federal judge will not extend deadline for mail-in ballots.
author: pemalevy

text: Bill Nelson is winning most of these contested ballots in Palm Beach, which is to be expected in a Dem county
author: pemalevy

text: The hand hand recount is wrapping up in Palm Bewch County. All that’s left is for the canvassing board to go over the ballots where voter intent couldn’t be determined. Here is the canvassing board, about to begin.
author: pemalevy

text: Hire. Ashley. Now. I’ve recorded multiple podcasts with Ashley and she is a pro reporter, editor, producer, and voice coach.
author: pemalevy

text: Hello from Palm Beach County, where the hand recount is just getting underway. Word here is they have about 5k ballots to check and that it will take less than 2 hours.
author: pemalevy

text: It's very likely that South Florida's slow mail system, coupled with strict mail in ballot laws, hurt Democrats in 2018. In 2020, it could be worse.
author: pemalevy

text: It doesn't help that this facility was shutdown at a critical time because of the mail bomb situation in late October.
author: pemalevy

text: All of the mail for Broward County goes through a Miami-Dade USPS facility that is notorious for being slow, is likely overworked, and in rundown city with crumbling roads. As a result, the mail in Broward is slow.
author: pemalevy

text:
Some people here in Broward County are quietly fearful that the region's slow mail delivery service, coupled with strict mail-in ballot rules, could have actually cost Nelson the Senate race--or at least had an effect.
https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/11/could-this-troubled-mail-distribution-center-have-changed-the-outcome-of-floridas-senate-race/ …
author: pemalevy

text: Broward County's hand recount for the Senate race is already over. But don't worry if you missed it. I woke up at 4:30am so I could tweet the whole thing for you.
author: pemalevy

text: The hand recount in Broward is over for the Senate race. It was a blur it went so fast. Looks like Nelson didn't come close to making up the ground he needs.
author: pemalevy

text: County Attoney tells room full of election workers: “I told my husband I would see him before midnight. I might see him for lunch.”
author: pemalevy

text: Breaking: Broward County just finished its hand recount in the Senate race. Waaaaay ahead of schedule. This is bad news for Nelson/Democrats
author: pemalevy

text: Folks on the floor here in Broward seem to agree that the vast majority of ballots here are “no votes” in the Senate race. Bad news for Nelson, who needs to pick up thousands here. Not on track to do that.
author: pemalevy

text: Rick Scott just picked up a vote here in Broward. Based on the rest of the ballot, gotta wonder if the voter crossed out the wrong one. No objection from Dems.
author: pemalevy

text: Rick Nelson just picked up a vote! JK, counted for Bill Nelson.
author: pemalevy

text: We have another contested ballot. Again, the board is calling this for Nelson. GOP objected. Voter appears to have started to fill in Scott, then filled in Nelson. Board counts it for Nelson.
author: pemalevy

text: We just had our first fight over a ballot. Voter appears to have filled in Scott, then scribbled it out and filled in Nelson. Canvassing board agrees it should count for Nelson. GOP team objects. Board counts it for Nelson.
author: pemalevy

text: Same thing happening at table 99. A lot of no votes in Senate race.
author: pemalevy

text: Here at table 79, they blew through a packet of ballots in about a minute. All “no vote” in the Senate race. If it happens like this all day, it’s bad news for Nelson. His team is betting that the undervote in Broward was a machine issue, not that ppl skipped the Senate race
author: pemalevy

text: The hand recount in Broward County has officially begun.
author: pemalevy

text: Here come the ballots. All the ballots to be recounted today are in these 29 bins
author: pemalevy

text: Here is the canvassing board and legal teams for each side. When a table encounters a ballot where voter  intent is u clear and/or two sides can’t agree, that ballot comes here for a final determination
author: pemalevy

text: The Broward County is going over the rules for how to evaluate each ballot. This includes the so-called “rule of consistency” that the Nelson team challenged in court as unconstitutional
author: pemalevy

text: At each table, volunteers will be sorting ballots. Here’s what each station looks like.
author: pemalevy

text: Good morning from recount HQ in Broward County, where the hand recount in the FL Senate race is set to begin at 7am. Here’s what it looks like.
author: pemalevy

text: Inside the room, this news sent shockwaves. For Dems, who need to add votes in Senate and governors races, this was a blow. If Nelson or Gillum had gained ground in the machine recount, we’ll never know.
author: pemalevy

text: To clarify: going forward, Broward’s official total in the 2018 midterm election will be preliminary (pre-recount) results + manually tabulated ballots + overseas/military
author: pemalevy

text: So the Florida secretary of state's official numbers for the Broward machine recount will actually be the preliminary numbers from Saturday.
author: pemalevy

text: This just happened: Broward failed to make the 3pm deadline. Election planning director uploaded results 2 minutes late due to "unfamiliarity" with the state's website. State did not accept recount numbers. "Basically, I just worked my ass off for nothing," the official said.
author: pemalevy

text: Broward official just read out latest recount results. There is still a significant undervote between Senate and governor totals, meaning the votes Nelson needs to win didn’t appear on the machines, or at least not enough. Tomorrow’s hand recount will determine if they exist.
author: pemalevy

text: More from Broward: The expected hand recounts will begin early tomorrow morning here. It’s expected to be a marathon 14 hours for hundreds of volunteers. And that’s just the Senate race. Deadline is noon Sunday.
author: pemalevy

text: Indeed
author: pemalevy

text: Here’s background on the 205 ballots, which spurred unfounded accusations of illegal voting and fraud from Republicans, including Marco Rubio
author: pemalevy

text: Brenda Snipes just announced she is including in the count 205 contested ballots, 22 of which were deemed invalid. She cannot segregate those out. She says she made the decision in conjunction with Florida law & to avoid disenfranchising valid votes
author: pemalevy

text: Broward County has finished its machine recount. They are about to transmit the results to the elections division in Tallahassee.
author: pemalevy

text: Hello from Palm Beach! Here is elections supervisor Susan Bucher telling press her county is unlikely to finish the Senate recount by 3pm deadline today. If that is indeed the case, she will resubmit the county’s initial totals from last Saturday. – bei Palm Beach County Supervisor Of Elections Support Center
author: pemalevy

text: Judge Walker: "The right of voters to cast their ballots and have them counted is guaranteed in the Constitution...Once again, Florida’s statutory scheme threatens that right by rejecting votes based on signature mismatch without an opportunity to challenge that determination."
author: pemalevy

text: Just happening in Florida: A federal judge just gave voters whose signatures were rejected until Saturday to fix the issue. The Scott campaign will immediately appeal
author: pemalevy

text: The Florida recount has been a cakewalk compared to what comes next in the hand recount.
author: pemalevy

text: Good morning from Broward elections HQ. The county has complete finished sorting ballots. It is moving through the machine recount. Staff are confident they will finish by the 3pm deadline tomorrow. (I would post another video but nothing is happening atm.)
author: pemalevy

text: The Florida recount is super exciting! But when you're on the inside, it's a little more tedious. (I literally just heard someone say "try to stay awake.") So here's how it really works.
author: pemalevy

text: And no, they are not announcing the results of this part of the recount.
author: pemalevy

text: It took Broward a few hours to count 299K early vote ballots. They are back to sorting for the rest of the day, but they successfully showed off their ability to tabulate quickly. And as they do it, they are pulling out ballots to count by hand for the expected manual recount.
author: pemalevy

text: We're officially in the lawsuit phase of the Florida recount. Here's what you need to know.
author: pemalevy

text: There was a fair bit of confusion this morning when the canvassing board announced they would begin counting before they had sorted a final batch of about 200k mail-in ballots. But the counting has begun, and they’ll get back to sorting later
author: pemalevy

text: The counting part of the recount in Broward County has officially begun this morning with the tabulation of early votes.
author: pemalevy

text: Update: The actual process of recounting has not begun in Broward County yet. The sorting process was supposed to end sometime in the night and the recount was then supposed to start. But when I showed up today, they were still sorting.
author: pemalevy

text: This process will likely end sometime late tonight, and then the official machine recount will begin.
author: pemalevy

text: Before Broward County performs its machine recount, it is sorting ballots. The goal is to separate the top page of each ballot, where the candidates are listed, with the other pages of the balllots. It looks like this:
author: pemalevy

text: The Rick Scott campaign went to court today for more security at Broward County supervisor of elections. The judge said he had "no evidence to enter a mandatory injunction." Parties agreed voluntarily to add 3 more sheriff's deputies to guard recount.
author: pemalevy

text: The parties have agreed to add 3 sheriff's deputies to monitor election process -- a small addition of security to a process that is already very secure.
author: pemalevy

text: Your tweet said "they got caught breaking law." I've spent the last two days observing the canvassing board and recount process in Boward County. If you went down there, you would see an orderly, transparent process, and lots of law enforcement watching.
author: pemalevy

text: Judge Tuter urges lawyers in his court room "to ramp down the rhetoric... words mean things these days.”
author: pemalevy

text: Judge Tuter: “No evidence to enter a mandatory injunction just now." But says the process needs more confidence and suggests the parties agree add more sheriff's officers. But clarifies that's not an order.
author: pemalevy

text: Scott's lawyer, Jason Zimmerman, sites as evidence for need of more security in Broward County election process past issues with Broward County supervisor of elections: "past is prologue."
author: pemalevy

text: Fla Dem lawyer to judge: “what could you possibly put in the record” as evidence of wrongdoing if you issue an injunction?
author: pemalevy

text: Lenny Samuels, lawyer for Florida Dems, argues that if the judge issues an injunction, it will send the message that something untoward has happened, when he says there is no evidence of it. He challenges that the Scott campaign has submitted no evidence.
author: pemalevy

text: I'm at the Broward County judicial complex in Fort Lauderdale where the Scott campaign is demanding more security to preserve integrity of the election. But Scott's campaign so far hasn't articulated very concrete requests for increasing already tight security.
author: pemalevy

text: Andrew Gillum and progressive groups in Florida are mobilizing against GOP claims of voter fraud behind a message of voting rights for all. “Maybe that’s the legacy of this election," Gillum told supporters.
author: pemalevy

text: Florida AG Pam Bondi—who is reportedly on Trump's shortlist for attorney general—is pushing Florida law enforcement to investigate fraud by election officials. Florida Dept of Law Enforcement already said they had no evidence of fraud.
author: pemalevy

text: Andrew Gillum makes the case to a church full of supporters in Fort Lauderdale, Broward County, that Florida's signature law and GOP's accusations of fraud are forms of voter disenfranchisement.
author: pemalevy

text: “Let our people in!” “Let our people in!” To be clear, there are Republicans inside. Some of these people watched a Dem lawyer help get a Republican inside.
author: pemalevy

text: The crowd outside is becoming obsessed with the fact that the room is full and a few Republican representatives haven’t been let in. They seem to think it’s a conspiracy to keep Republicans out.
author: pemalevy

text: The scene outside the Broward County Supervisor of Elections office is basically a small pro-Trump picnic, complete with patriotic pop country tunes coming out of a pick-up truck and a box of donuts.
author: pemalevy

text: Bill Nelson's narrow path to victory, if it exists, runs through Broward County. But Republicans are already pre-butting their efforts by claiming the county is engaged in fraud.
author: pemalevy

text: I spoke to one of the voters Rubio claims broke the law. She is 29 and works 2 jobs. She followed instructions at her polling station & provided a valid photo ID. She has no idea why her ballot was rejected. Likely her signature was deemed a mismatch  https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/11/one-voter-broward-county-florida-election/ …
author: pemalevy

text: The ones disgarded for mismatch would be in the first 10.1K batch?
author: pemalevy

text: Can I add a question to this thread: any idea how many ballots were thrown out due to mismatched signature and could be added back in if Nelson wins his lawsuit?
author: pemalevy

text: Rep. Matt Gaetz is giving a press conference/rally speech outside Broward County supervisor of elections’ office to allege voter fraud.  His supporters, who have been outside protesting, are cheering.
author: pemalevy

text: Scene outside the Broward County Supervisor is Elections is loud with protesters on both sides going strong
author: pemalevy

text: Small Correction: Not 25 ballots, 25 pages of ballots. Unclear how many voters implicated here. Fate of these votes remains undetermined.
author: pemalevy

text: Canvassing board members are noting the objections but proceeding anyway.
author: pemalevy

text: Update from Florida: Broward County ran out of time to review 25 ballots before the noon deadline to submit results to SoS. They are now reviewing them after sending in tallies. Republican lawyers object to counting all 25 because they are being reviewed after the deadline.
author: pemalevy

text: I’m at the Broward Supervisor of Elections office. Police have cordoned off the press. A few protestors from each party are outside. Lawyers for the Democrats and Nelson just arrived.
author: pemalevy

text: If Broward County had removed thousands of voters this year in a process that removes more poor/minority/Dem voters, these razor-tight races would be closer or won by GOP. BTW, the case is being appealed last i checked.
author: pemalevy

text: Here’s a fact about Broward County’s Election supervisor: she was sued by a GOP activist & member of Trump’s election integrity commission to force the county to purge its voter rolls. This March, she won. If thousands of extra voters had been purged, you can imagine the chaos...
author: pemalevy

text: Ok that's all. But I'll be in Florida this weekend. Reach out if you have a story.
author: pemalevy

text: It also happened in Georgia this year. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/10/georgia-county-and-secretary-of-state-sued-for-rejecting-minority-absentee-ballots-at-high-rates/ … Repeatedly, courts have struck down or modified these laws, finding their application unconstitutional.
author: pemalevy

text: Research shows that signature matching laws disenfranchise legitimate voters. Minority and young voters' ballots are rejected at significantly higher rates than white voters. This happened in recent elections in Florida, including this election.
author: pemalevy

text: She continued: "Long story short, I had the attention of the entire room and all of the concerned citizens that were there to watch the ballots be counted. It carried on well after 5 PM. I won. The board unanimously agreed that my ballot should be counted."
author: pemalevy

text: "They kept denying me, and denying me again, and I asked if I could petition the board against their decision. It was granted....
author: pemalevy

text: Alexa drove an hour to her canvassing board at 4pm on Thursday. Just under the wire, she pleaded with them to accept her ballot. Here's what happened next, in her own words:
author: pemalevy

text: Now, it was up to the county canvassing board whether to accept the provisional ballot. She had until 5pm on Thursday to make her case to them. Here's what happened next:
author: pemalevy

text: After Election Day, she learned provisional ballot was not counted. Technically, even if her absentee ballot was rejected, she had already voted, so now she had voted twice...
author: pemalevy

text: To "cure" this problem, voters must send in a signed affidavit and a copy of their ID. Alexa did not want to do this b/c she fears identity theft. Instead, she went to an early vote center and cast a provisional ballot in person.
author: pemalevy

text: This Florida voter is in Volusia County, and her name is Alexa. In a series of emails to me, she relayed her story. I haven't further verified it. She has been voting absentee for decades. But this time, the canvassing board rejected her ballot as having a mismatched signature.
author: pemalevy

text: Here is a story about how one Florida voter overcame the signature match law and made her sure ballot counted—the law the Senate campaign is now suing over. It's a saga.
author: pemalevy

text: So according to Mitchell's former colleague, her memo does not meet the standards she sets for her own office. Instead, Long sees it as a product of political bias, discarding prosecutorial expertise rather than deploying it.
author: pemalevy

text: Fourth, Mitchell points out that Ford does not remember key details. “Again, I was trained by Ms. Mitchell about how trauma explicitly does prevent memory from happening...I was trained explicitly by Ms. Mitchell to identify that as corroborative,” Long told me.
author: pemalevy

text: Third, Mitchell says the potential witnesses failed to corroborate Dr. Ford's account in signed statements to the Senate committee. Long says using this to discredit Ford is "bullshit." He calls these "unreliable" "hearsay" that fail any "standard that Ms. Mitchell would allow"
author: pemalevy

text: “I challenge Ms. Mitchell directly on this issue because her office often charges cases with a very expanded timeline,” says Long. “I was trained explicitly by her to not consider this time thing as an inconsistency."
author: pemalevy

text: Second, Mitchell emphasizes that Dr. Ford alternately referred to the early 1980s and mid 1980s in discussing her assault. Mitchell points to this as a reason to doubt her story. Long, her former colleague, says this is a different standard than one her own office uses...
author: pemalevy

text: First, why did she apply the standards of criminal liability when she knows that the case hasn't been given an adequate investigation to reach a conclusion on that front. “Mitchell doesn’t have sufficient information to even draw these conclusions,” he said.
author: pemalevy

text: “I’m very disappointed in my former boss and mentor,” says Matthew Long, who was trained by Mitchell as a sex crimes prosecutor and spent 12 years as a prosecutor in Arizona. Here are some of the biggest problems with Mitchell's memo, according to Long:
author: pemalevy

text: Rachel Mitchell's former colleague tells Mitchell's memo is "absolutely disingenuous" and not up to the standards of her own office:
author: pemalevy

text: Blumenthal on Dr. Ford: "Her name will be in the history books. Long after ours are gone, she will be remembered."
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Klobuchar: "What are you hiding? What would it hurt?... What is he afraid of if we just spend one week looking at the evidence?"
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Klobuchar: "The chairman even thanked [Dr. Ford] for her bravery. Where is the bravery in this room?"
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Whitehouse issues a warning: "Overtime I expect that facts to come out... The sand is running through Kavanaugh's hourglass. And I pledge whatever I can do to make sure that the truth of his conduct is ultimately determined."
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Whitehouse just held up Kavanaugh's calendar, points to July 1, 1982, and says this may be powerful corroborating evidence.
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Cornyn says "dozens of witnesses" couldn't confirm Ramirez's allegations, then "no one" could confirm. This is simply not true. There are plenty of people who heard about it at the time. The number of people in the room were just a handful.
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Leahy reminds the Judiciary Committee of the multiple times Kavanaugh lied under oath:
author: pemalevy

text: Leahy today: "Time and time again, when confronted under oath about his involvement in Bush-era scandals... Judge Kavanaugh misled the Senate."
author: pemalevy

text: Presumably Jeff Flake wants to return to politics and run for president one day. This will haunt him if he does.
author: pemalevy

text: Feinstein calls Kavanaugh vote "a real test... to see how we treat women."
author: pemalevy

text: Feinstein notes that Kavanaugh's temper tantrum yesterday is not becoming of a justice on the highest court in the land.
author: pemalevy

text: So far, no one on the GOP side of the aisle seems to have believed Dr. Ford.
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Tillis: "You're the first major target of a new strategy"
author: pemalevy

text: With all the talk of Brett Kavanaugh being put through "hell" and how every one of the past 10 days has been "an eternity," it's striking that there has been no recognition of the actual lifetime Dr. Ford has spent dealing with the fallout from the alleged sexual assault.
author: pemalevy

text: I guess the Republicans don't need the female prosecutor anymore
author: pemalevy

text: Lindsay Graham looks like he's auditioning for attorney general right now.
author: pemalevy

text: Kavanaugh: "Thanks to what some of you on this side of the committee have unleashed, I may never get to teach again... I may never be able to coach again."
author: pemalevy

text: Kavanaugh says no one helped him write this speech. On that, I believe him.
author: pemalevy

text: Wait, why does it have to be a weekend? No one had get togethers on weekday evenings?
author: pemalevy

text: Actually, legally speaking, there is corroboration. As a lawyer, Graham should know that. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/09/kavanaugh-says-the-claims-against-him-are-uncorroborated-legally-speaking-thats-not-true/ …
author: pemalevy

text: Blumenthal on why he believes Dr. Ford: “Someone who is honest… is also candid about what she or he cannot remember.”
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Klobuchar asks Dr. Ford what don’t you forget? She answers: “The stairwell… the bed on the right side of the room... the multiple attempts to escape, and the final ability to do so.”
author: pemalevy

text: Dr. Ford requests some caffeine. She is on Pacific Time after all.
author: pemalevy

text: Dr. Ford: "I'm an independent person and I am no one's pawn."
author: pemalevy

text: Dr. Ford: "I've had to relive this trauma in front of the world."
author: pemalevy

text: Feinstein: “This is not a trial of Dr. Ford, it’s a job interview of Judge Kavanaugh… Is he the best we can do?”
author: pemalevy

text: Kavanaugh on allegations against him: "These are smears, pure and simple... they are also a threat to any man or woman who wishes to serve our country"
author: pemalevy

text: I'm so sorry. I hope you find him!
author: pemalevy

text: Change is hard when Congress/government does basically nothing to require it. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/07/the-midterm-elections-are-in-serious-danger-of-being-hacked-thanks-to-trump/ …
author: pemalevy

text: Two Republican congressman mingled with a notorious rightwing troll and alleged Holocaust denier. Again.
author: pemalevy

text: A must-read thread, particularly in light of the likely Kavanaugh confirmation
author: pemalevy

text: "Bring it" -- Cory Booker to John Cornyn when he suggests penalty for releasing confidential document could be expulsion from the Senate.
author: pemalevy

text: The Times decided to make itself the story when it should be the Kavanaugh hearings. In return, all we know is an official feels righteous about their decision to stay in the admin, though they provided no evidence that they are stemming catastrophe rather than enabling it.
author: pemalevy

text: Kavanaugh is right, foreign spending on so-called issue advocacy was not at issue in the case. That's why it was so shocking that Kavanaugh went ahead and took a swipe at that part of the law anyway in his opinion. It was totally unnecessary.
author: pemalevy

text:
Klobuchar: "Your opinion left open the possibility of unlimited spending by foreign nationals" in US elections. "A Russian company… actually cited your opinion" against Mueller 
Kavanaugh: "I'm not sure—the state of the law and expenditure limits was not before us in that case."
author: pemalevy

text: Update: Sen. Klobuchar just asked Kavanaugh about this in his confirmation hearing. He claimed to not understand what she was talking about, remember his own opinion, or understand its ramifications.
author: pemalevy

text: Update: Sen. Klobuchar just asked Kavanaugh about this in his hearing. He appeared not to understand what she was talking about, not to remember his own opinion, not to be aware of its ramifications in Mueller probe.

text: Thread
author: pemalevy

text: To non-citizens who are not legal permanent residents, "Congress said you may not give money or spend money in an attempt to influence an election. Period. Kavanaugh implemented a huge carveout."
author: pemalevy

text: As election law expert @rickhasen told WaPo this summer: Kavanaugh created “potentially a huge loophole for foreign and undisclosed issue ads on federal elections.”
author: pemalevy

text: In February, special counsel Robert Mueller handed down a stunning indictment against 13 Russians and 3 Russian companies for interfering in the 2016 election... Surprisingly, there were no election-related charges. The reason is almost certainly a ruling by Brett Kavanaugh.
author: pemalevy

text: How Brett Kavanaugh made Russian election interference easier and Robert Mueller's job harder—A campaign finance case that should be front and center in this week's hearings
author: pemalevy

text: "The question of self-pardons is something I have never analyzed," Kavanaugh says on whether Trump can pardon himself. Says he won't answer "hypothetical questions of that sort."
author: pemalevy

text: Sen. Susan Collins says she was a target or Russian trolls, whose tweets reached hundreds of thousands of people. She asks Twitter CEO why she found out about it from Clemson University database, and not from Twitter.
author: pemalevy

text: Kavanaugh is now discussing the power of federal agencies to make regulations—he is skeptical of agency discretion and likely to strike down regulations, with repercussions for everything environment to labor to consumer protection and on and on
author: pemalevy

text: That's from @Pinboard
author: pemalevy

text: A telling anecdote about campaign cybersecurity: "Two weeks ago, after a hacking scare, the DCCC sent an urgent email to all campaigns titled 'Reminder About Cybersecurity.' That email included three attachments, one of them advising not to send or open email attachments."
author: pemalevy

text: In Kavanaugh hearing, Sen. Whitehouse says any judge would grant a continuance when one side does a document dump of 40k documents the day before trial. Says confirmation hearing should likewise be delayed.
author: pemalevy

text: In 2016, the Russians attacked on three fronts: hacking our voting systems, spreading disinformation on social media, and hacking the DNC/DCCC/Podesta. Congress has acknowledged the need to fix the first two—but has done nothing to protect campaigns. Neither has the Trump admin.
author: pemalevy

text: Campaigns are at serious risk of being hacked—in fact, several already have been—yet Congress is doing nothing to protect campaigns and parties from cyberattacks that could disrupt the midterms
author: pemalevy

text: Here’s the kicker: documents show that the consultant who sold precinct consolidation as a cost-savings plan invoiced the county over $12k— more than his plan would save in an election year
author: pemalevy

text: Some news out of Randolph County, Ga, where the election board planned to close 7 of 9 voting sites until a public outcry derailed the plan. A draft presentation on the plan stresses cost savings, not ADA compliance, the official reason for the plan
author: pemalevy

text: After the Supreme Court allowed counties to close precincts without federal approval, the number of precincts in Georgia has shrunk, often in rural, poor, and minority communities. Randolph County brought attention to the issue, but it's not the only place that it's an issue.
author: pemalevy

text: Straight from Jeanine Pirro's show to Trump's brain.
author: pemalevy

text: After drawing the attention of the entire nation, a black-majority county in Georgia will not shutter 7 of its 9 voting sites this November.
author: pemalevy

text: + Congress cancels markup of election security bill
author: pemalevy

text: In a statement, Sen. Klobuchar (D) suggests that *bipartisan* Secure Elections Act markup was derailed today b/c it didn't have enough GOP votes. She says Rs Blunt and Lankford "tried valiantly to salvage the votes for this bill on the Republican side."
author: pemalevy

text: Read this thread. Trump DOJ using one civil rights law to disenfranchise minority voters.
author: pemalevy

text: wow
author: pemalevy

text:
A Haiku: 

At work to cover
A hearing, on my birthday...
Now it is canceled
author: pemalevy

text: *unconstitutionally denied (according to a federal judge)
author: pemalevy

text: So here we are, months from a major election and Congress is sitting on their hands when it comes to election security. Here's my recent @MotherJones story on how vulnerable we are—and why Republicans are MIA on election security
author: pemalevy

text: For two years, Republicans have avoided holding hearings on Russian hacking of election systems and campaigns. There's a lot of blame to go around, but the fact that Republicans won't hold a hearing on a bill that has bipartisan support is bad news.
author: pemalevy

text: Election security bill markup canceled today. Russia interfered in myriad ways in our basic process of holding elections. Two years later, and with midterms approaching, Republicans can't even hold a hearing to discuss some pretty basic security upgrades.
author: pemalevy

text: When a woman he slept with got pregnant, this Trump official took her to get an abortion. Now he’s on a crusade to stop migrants from having their own. Exclusive from @H_Lev
author: pemalevy

text: A majority-black county in Georgia plans to shutter 7 of 9 polling locations for the November elections. This is the kind of voter suppression technique that the Supreme Court greenlighted when it gutted the Voting Rights Act. https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/08/15/us/ap-us-polling-places-proposed-closures.html …
author: pemalevy

text: Kris Kobach is Kansas' GOP nominee for governor. And thanks to an independent spoiler candidate, he may well get the job in November.
author: pemalevy

text: This is horrific
author: pemalevy

text: We are entering an era where the claims and policies of voter fraud alarmists are put to the test in court. In Florida, Adams lost a voter purge case. Kobach lost his proof-of-citizenship. Now voter fraud scholarship could be headed for trial.
author: pemalevy

text: Yesterday, a federal judge (and George W appointee) allowed the lawsuit to go forward on all claims. https://www.southerncoalition.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/LULAC-MTD-Order.pdf …
author: pemalevy

text: So this spring, a civil rights group sued Adams for defamation and voter intimidation under two civil rights statutes
author: pemalevy

text: The data was very dubious, and many eligible citizen voters were named in the reports, along with the personal information such as contact info and addresses.
author: pemalevy

text: In 2016 and 2017, J. Christian Adams, who went on to join Trump's election integrity commission, published reports claiming thousands of "aliens" were voting in Virginia. His reports suggested these people were felons, and included personal identifying information on them.
author: pemalevy

text: The ongoing Kobach-Colyer primary in Kansas is a sign of what's to come when partisan secretaries of state oversee their own elections—esp when they put policies in place that suppress turnout
author: pemalevy

text: It’s Not Just Kobach: Three Vote-Suppressing Secretaries of State Are Overseeing Their Own Elections in 2018 https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/08/its-not-just-kobach-three-vote-suppressing-secretaries-of-state-are-overseeing-their-own-elections/ …
author: pemalevy

text: Florida is also the site of a closely contested Senate race that could determine which party controls the US Senate next year. This hack comes on the heals of an attempted hack of Claire McCaskill's campaign, another Democrat in a tough reelection campaign.
author: pemalevy

text: Florida was a target of the Russians in 2016. As a key swing state where, as history has shown, a national election can come down to a few counties, Russia can do a lot of damage to the integrity of our elections by interfering in Florida.
author: pemalevy

text: As a reminder, Florida's secretary of state initially said that new federal monies available for cybersecurity would not be put to use in 2018. But after counties begged for the funds and the governor forced his hand, he relented.
author: pemalevy

text: The Russians have penetrated Florida's election systems ahead of 2018, Senator says. “They have already penetrated certain counties in the state and they now have free rein to move about.”
author: pemalevy

text: I have podcasted. The latest Mother Jones Podcast episode features @AJVicens and I talking about election hacking, and how the Trump administration and GOP have in many ways failed to rise to this challenge.
author: pemalevy

text: Bolton assures reporters at press briefing that Trump did press Putin on election meddling in Helsinki. His source? Putin.
author: pemalevy

text: I love this.
author: pemalevy

text: A bribery trial revealed how closely Jeff Sessions worked with some of his biggest campaign donors to block an EPA cleanup of a poor Birmingham neighborhood
author: pemalevy

text: After the hanging chads fiasco of 2000, Congress spent ~ $4 billion to upgrade election systems. Now those are old, insecure, and have been hacked by the Russians. But Congress will spare just $380 million (which was actually left over from the $4 billion appropriated in 2002).
author: pemalevy

text: Yes, Congress already gave states $380 million for FY2018. But most experts I've talked to describe that as a downpayment, maybe 10-15% of what is needed to secure elections in the US. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/07/the-midterm-elections-are-in-serious-danger-of-being-hacked-thanks-to-trump/ …
author: pemalevy

text: But w/o prez and Congress firmly behind them, it's been patchy, lacking major resources and coordination. An enormous opportunity avoided by people afraid Trump will ruin their careers with a tweet.
author: pemalevy

text: The takeaway: For 2 yrs since we our election systems were hacked, Congress avoided tackling the problem head-on. Some officials/agencies are doing good work...
author: pemalevy
